slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Hello everyone! Welcome to the lecture on ethics in educational research.

This lecture has four objectives:

1. Introduction to ethics

2. Background and Law

3. Ethical Research: The IRB

4. Ethical Principles
No Audio

We’d like to assume that research will be conducted in ways that protect the dignity of all people.

- that the ends will never justify the means.

- that research will be conducted for the common good.

But it hasn’t always been so. Only a few decades ago, national research involving human subjects was occasionally conducted in such a way that was highly detrimental—if not fatal—to subjects.

In some studies, scientists injected elderly patients with cancer cells to determine if people could “catch” cancer. Other researchers injected mentally handicapped children at a children’s hospital with the hepatitis virus to study the effects of the disease.

Still others prescribed placebos instead of effective medicine to military servicemen to investigate the course of their ailment.

What are ethics?

The word “ethic” comes from the Greek word “ethos,” which refers to character or guiding beliefs.

Current use of “ethics” refers to standards and principles for the purpose of guiding conduct.

They are also rules of behavior to identify right from wrong.

Applied to education research, ethics are how we make our decisions when it come to the conduct, reporting, and use of research findings.

Back in 1932, the Tuskegee Study was designed to investigated the effects of syphilis on the human body. Doctors knew that syphilis led to dementia and eventually killed people, but they wanted to study exactly how the disease progressed.

“The research subjects were black prison inmates who had syphilis and who had consented to the research after being told they would receive treatment for the illness.

“Penicillin had been used effectively to treat syphilis since the 1940s. However, the investigators gave the patients placebos—instead of penicillin, allowing the disease to run its course. They then studied the effects of the disease on the inmates. In 1974, the Associate Press broke a story condemning the Tuskegee Study which caused public uproars. This story effectively ended the 40-year study. The AP story also helped set in motion several actions that resulted in federal laws that codified ethical principles and practice for research that involves human subjects.

This timeline highlights the key events that lead up to the creation of federal ethical codes and guidelines.

(1974 Panel)

The National Research Act of 1974 provided mechanisms for the protection of human subjects. The Act also provides for institutional review of all behavioral research involving human subjects (including educational research) and requires informed consent of human subjects.

(1979 Panel)

In 1979, the National Commission issued “Ethical Principles and Guidelines for the protection of Human Subjects of Research,” which is also known as the Belmont Report.
There are three core principles to the Belmont Report: respect for person, beneficence, and justice.

There are three core principles to the Belmont Report: respect for person, beneficence, and justice.

First, respect for person is best represented through Informed consent–written document that includes:

- Purpose of the study

- Expected duration

- Explanation of what participation involves

- Benefits and risks to participants

- Procedures for maintaining confidentiality

- Statement that the subject may discontinue participation at any time

You can see a few sample consent forms from the resources link at the University IRB website. The link is provided here.

Second, the principle of beneficence refers to that researchers should “do no harm” and they should minimize risks and maximize benefits. Researchers should also keep all data confidential, including subjects’ names or any identifiable information.

Third, the principle of justice is about fairness. The justice principles requires that the benefits and burdens of research are equitably distributed. For example, a study was conducted on mentally disabled boys institutionalized at school in Massachusetts, where the boys were intentionally fed radioactive iron and calcium in breakfast cereal to study adult nutrition and metabolism. The adults received the benefits of the study but the children bore the brunt of the research. Participants should come from the group that benefits from the study. This principle is go provide guards against use of samples of convenience and vulnerable populations.

Let’s talk about the origin of peer review. Committees on research involving human subjects evolved after the Nuremburg Trials, especially after some of the horrific outcomes done by doctors at the Nazi prison camps, Institutional Review Boards became commonplace in the 1960s.

The Tuskegee study was one of the most important factors leading to the establishment in the late 1960s of institutional review boards (IRBs) to formally peer review scientists research projects. The government established IRBs because scientists needed to be reviewed by their peers. Peer review provides a check on scientists or researchers whether their hypotheses or methods are legitimate and to make sure that they have disclosed all information.

Now let’s talk about the Institutional Review Board or IRB. The University of St. Thomas IRB is responsible for reviewing proposed research studies to make sure that the rights, safety, and welfare of people recruited for studies conducted by St. Thomas faculty, students, and staff. This include student action research that will be implemented in the field. Action research proposals do not require IRB review.

There are three levels of review.

First, exempt review refers to studies that are:

- Very low risk such as anonymous survey

- Research that involves normal educational practices

- Research using publicly-available data

The IRB director will determine if a study should be exempted of IRB review.

Second, research projects that involve minimal risks, the participant involvement is higher than the exempt level, or the projects involve children, at a minimum, should be considered expedited. This is considered expedited because only one or two IRB members or the chair may review the application rather than the full board.

Third, any projects that are not at the exempt or expedited levels require full board review. A research project that involves greater than minimal risks or using vulnerable populations such as prisoners, children, or pregnant women would require a majority of the IRB Committee to review and discuss the study.

You can learn more about the IRB process from the stthomas.edu/irb website.

When conducting a research project, a researcher needs to ask a subject to sign the consent form. The purposes of informed consent are:

• Uses language that the subject can understand.

• Includes a reasonable explanation of the research, it’s purpose, procedures, and duration of participation.

• Describes any benefits or risks to the subject

• Describes any appropriate alternative measures.

• Describes the extent to which confidentiality of records will be maintained.

• Gives the subject a reasonable opportunity to consider whether or not to participate.

In the final slide, we will discuss ethical and legal standards in educational research. Both American Education Research Association (AERA) and APA have developed ethical guidelines for authoring and publishing research. They are:

1-Avoid conflicts of interest: If an organization or professional association hires someone to conduct a research to promote its cause, the research might not be free of bias. For example, we should be cautious about the research conducted by the National Milk Producer Federation on the benefits of milk. We need to make sure that a researcher does not have a vest interest in the findings or results.

2-Ensure accuracy: It is unethical to falsify data for publication. Researchers need to present original or accurate data.

3-Protect intellectual property rights: There are two ways to do this:

Avoid plagiarism: Researchers should give credit where credit is due when citing other people’s work. Researchers should also avoid self-plagiarism by duplicating previous work without proper citations.

Establish authorship: Only people with substantial contributions such as contributing theories, deriving hypothesis, designing data collection, conducting data analysis, or concluding findings should be recognized in authorship. The principle author should be listed first. If the authorship is alphabetical, a not should be provided to indicate equal contribution or not.

Here’s a quick summary of today’s lecture.

In this lecture, we discussed:

• A brief history of ethics code

• Background of national Laws

• The IRB levels

• Ethical Principles in authoring and publishing
